data.title: Research Guides at College of Coastal Georgia
data.meta_description: Robert Sengstacke Abbott, a pioneer of America's black press, was born on St. Simons Island, Georgia. This Research Guide is an introduction to his life and and serves as a starting point for more research on the history of the black press in America.
data.text:
The African American Biographical Database includes resources from a variety of biographical dictionaries and other sources.

Research Tip: When doing a Profile Search, enter the last name first. If nothing comes up, try Full Text Search.

Chambliss, Rollin. What Negro Newspapers of Georgia Say About Some Social Problems, 1933. Athens, Ga, 1934. Print. Call Number: E185.61 .C52

Giddings, Paula. Ida: A Sword Among Lions : Ida B. Wells and the Campaign against Lynching. New York, N.Y.: Amistad, 2008. Print. Call Number: E185.97.W55 G53

Jacobs, Donald M. Antebellum Black Newspapers: Indices to New York Freedom's Journal (1827-1829), The Rights of All (1829), The Weekly Advocate (1837), and The Colored American (1837-1841). Westport, Conn.: Greenwood Press, 1976. Print. Call Number: E185.5 .J33

Jordan, William G. Black Newspapers and America's War for Democracy, 1914-1920. Chapel Hill: University of North Carolina Press, 2001. Print. Call Number: PN4882.5 .J67 2001

La Brie, Henry G. The Black Newspaper in America: A Guide. [Iowa City]: Institute for Communication Studies, University of Iowa, 1970. Print. Call Number: Z6944.N39 L3

Robinson, Rhondda Elaine. Black-controlled Newspapers in Atlanta, 1970-1985: Still Burdened By the Message and Struggling to Survive. 1988. Print. Call Number: LXC15 1988 .R663

Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture. Freedom's Journals: A History of the Black Press in New York State : An Exhibition, At the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture, January 30-April 30, 1986. [New York]: New York Public Library, Astor, Lenox and Tilden Foundations, 1986. Print. Call Number: PN4882.5 .F74 1986
